;当甲壳虫乐队在 50 多年前解散时，悲痛欲绝的歌迷们渴望更多的。现在，人工智能正提供这样的服务。

;

;从“重聚”四人组独唱生涯的歌曲，到重新演绎幸存的超级巨星保罗·麦卡特尼 (Paul McCartney) 的后期作品，让他的声音恢复到年轻时的巅峰状态，新的创作炫耀这项技术已经走了多远，并提出了一系列道德和法律问题。

;

;“我哭了！这真是太美了！！！”一位听众在典型的 YouTube 评论中为麦卡特尼 2013 年单曲 New 的粉丝创作的 AI 翻唱写了一篇评论，该曲以去老化的人声和由他伟大的歌曲创作伙伴和朋友已故的约翰·列侬“演唱”的桥梁部分为特色。;

;同样令人印象深刻的是《与我一起变老》的一个版本，这是列侬最后创作的歌曲之一，在列侬 1980 年被谋杀后发行，最近由一位名叫“Dae Lims”的 AI 创作者重新制作。;

;凭借增强的音质、管弦乐编曲和和谐的伴唱，让人想起利物浦摇滚乐队的全盛时期，这首歌最激动人心的时刻出现在麦卡特尼低吟着一段飙升的旋律和关于衰老的凄美歌词时。

;

;“当我听到这个时，我失去了它。我开始哭了，”音乐 YouTuber Steve Onotera（他的昵称是“SamuraiGuitarist”，拥有一百万粉丝）在最近的一段视频中说道，他讨论了新作品意想不到的情感共鸣。

;

;在历史上最具影响力的乐队之后他说，激烈地分道扬镳，粉丝们被剥夺了最后的“幸福结局”。 “因此，当我们确实看到由 AI 人为但令人信服地创造的重聚时，嗯，它令人惊讶地情绪化。”

;

;就像早期的一首名为 Heart on a Sleeve 的曲目，其中包含 AI 生成的 Drake 和 The Weeknd 的人声以及在 TikTok 和其他平台上获得了数百万次点击，这些封面使用抓取技术分析和捕捉特定声音的细微差别。

;

;你会被你的 AI 克隆取代吗？也许有一天，但还不是现在

;

;创作者可能会自己演唱这些部分，然后应用克隆的声音，其方式类似于在照片上放置滤镜。

;

;虽然结果可能令人惊讶，但实现目标并不简单，需要熟练的操作人员将新的人工智能工具与传统音乐处理软件的广泛知识相结合，多伦多语音克隆公司 Resemble AI 的首席执行官 Zohaib Ahmed 说。

;

;“我认为我们仍然看到一小部分人甚至可以访问这些工具，”他说。他们需要“跳过障碍，阅读文档，拥有合适的计算机，然后将它们组合在一起。”

;

;Ahmed 的公司是提供平台的公司之一，该平台可以让客户更容易地访问该技术娱乐行业——最近由已故艺术偶像安迪·沃霍尔 (Andy Warhol) “讲述”的 Netflix 纪录片系列取得了早期的成功。

;

;斯坦福大学计算机中心的作曲家兼助理教授帕特里夏·亚历山德里尼 (Patricia Alessandrini)在音乐和声学研究中，最近大量的 AI 曲目代表了一项技术的成熟，该技术一直呈指数级发展——但在过去十年中基本上不为公众所知。

;

;“这是一个人工智能做得很好的一个很好的例子，这是任何相似的东西：在现有的东西上训练它，”她说。

;

;但是，她补充说，当涉及到新想法时，它会陷入困境。 “真的没有人指望它会取代人类创造艺术和文化的丰富历史。”

;

;对于音乐行业来说，其影响是巨大的。随着技术的进步，可以轻松让人们将自己的声音变成他们最喜欢的歌手之一的软件可能并不遥远。

;

;AI 竞赛中的 Deepfake 色情内容可能会“永远毁掉”女性

;< p>;“如果他们获得声乐执照的报酬，嘿，每个人都很高兴，”Onotera 说。 “但如果他们早就去世了怎么办？这取决于他们的财产吗？”

;

;事实证明，AI 对版权世界产生了巨大的影响。

;

;就《袖珍心》而言，环球音乐集团很快提出版权主张，并从流媒体服务中撤下了该曲目，但这并没有阻止它在小账户上重新出现。

;

;纽约音乐版权律师马克·奥斯特罗 (Marc Ostrow) 说人工智能生成的音乐是一个“灰色地带”。

;

;版权可以由使用材料的词曲作者以及母带录音的持有者主张。

;

;另一方面hand AI 创作者可以辩称它属于“合理使用”，并引用 2015 年的一项法院裁决，该裁决称谷歌被允许存档世界上的书籍，因为它没有与卖家竞争并且只显示片段。

;

;最后然而，本月，美国最高法院裁定已故流行歌星普林斯的沃霍尔版画侵犯了拍摄原始图像的摄影师的版权。

;

;此外，名人可以根据“宣传权”保护自己的肖像，该权利是在 1980 年代末 Bette Midler 成功起诉福特汽车公司在广告中使用听起来像她的歌手而确立的。

;

;“做你自己”就足够了”：流行歌手通过 AI 歌曲在中国走红

;

;最终，“我认为可能会有自愿的行业标准……或者将通过诉讼来实现，”Ostrow 说。

;

;权利持有人还需要考虑对明显是粉丝创作的致敬作品而不打算用于货币化的作品提起诉讼可能带来的负面公关。]

;越来越多的中国投资者转向埃及寻找通往国际市场的捷径，感谢靠近苏伊士运河、该国慷慨的税收优惠以及地处亚洲、非洲和欧洲交界处的位置。

;

;最近几个月，埃及与中国公司达成了价值超过 80 亿美元的投资协议，用于其苏伊士运河经济区 (SCZONE)。作为北京全球基础设施计划“一带一路”倡议的一部分，它由中国和埃及政府共同建设。

;

;该区域面积超过 455 平方公里（176 平方英里），由天津经济技术开发区（泰达），此后吸引了数百家公司，其中大部分是中国公司。

;

;在开发区内，中国建造了一个 7.34 平方公里的工业区，称为泰达城，这是一个联合企业由天津泰达投资控股有限公司和中非发展基金资助的风险投资。

;

;埃及正在提供更多的税收和投资优惠以吸引投资者，特别是在汽车行业、绿色氢燃料项目和配套行业。

;

;它希望将其苏伊士运河经济区定位为绿色燃料贸易的区域中心。苏伊士运河经济区是一个沿运河开发的大型工业和物流区，由六个主要港口和四个工业区组成。它依靠中国公司来实现这一雄心。

;

;美国的铁路计划能否吸引中东国家远离中国的“一带一路”？

;

;例如，中国国有能源集团中国Energy Engineering Corporation，也称为 Energy China，计划建造一座价值 51 亿美元的绿色氢工厂，将向欧洲市场出口氨。

;

;总部位于华盛顿的咨询公司 McLarty Associates 的经理 Mohammed Soliman 表示，苏伊士运河的战略位置和对全球贸易的重要性使其对中国公司具有吸引力。这条水道连接地中海和红海，是亚洲和欧洲之间最短的海上通道，也是北京最大的市场。

;

;Soliman 说，中国企业尤其对投资苏伊士运河经济区表现出了兴趣.

;

;“这项投资使中国公司能够更有效地进入非洲和欧洲市场，并利用运河的战略地位，”索利曼说。

;

;5 月下旬，一个埃及苏伊士运河经济区代表团访问了北京、天津、广州、杭州和香港等中国城市，交易额超过 30 亿美元，涵盖化学品、纺织品和服装、电力、管道、铁和钢铁行业签署了协议。

;

;开罗寄希望于其苏伊士运河，每年有超过 10% 的全球贸易或约 18,000 艘船只通过该运河，其中许多运载来自中国的货物运往欧洲、非洲和中东

;

;在访问期间，苏伊士运河经济区主席 Walid Gamal el Din 会见了新兴球墨铸铁管董事长贾士瑞，讨论了拟在苏伊士运河西北部的苏赫纳工业区建设 20 亿美元的管道制造厂苏伊士湾。

;

;该投资将每年生产 250,000 吨球墨铸铁管，并计划在第二阶段将产量翻一番，此外还有每年 15,000 吨铸件。

;< p>;埃及代表团会见了总部位于北京的 Hidier Power Group 的官员，并与中非泰达投资有限公司签署了两项价值 3.65 亿美元的交易，以在开发区建设发电厂和先进燃烧系统设施。

;

;中国之行期间，石化生产商山东天一公司计划在泰达市建设溴素、烧碱等工业化学品生产装置，总投资3.1亿美元。

;

;作为该计划的一部分乘风钢铁和中材 CDI 投资 3 亿美元，将在苏伊士运河经济区建设占地 750,000 平方米（800 万平方英尺）的钢铁生产基地，分两期实施。

;

;根据 Gamal el Din 的说法，大约有 137 家公司和 51 家工厂在该区内注册和运营。

;

;在该区运营的主要中国公司之一是全球最大的玻璃纤维制造商巨石集团，该公司设立了其埃及业务于 2012 年在泰达城成立，目前产能为 340,000 吨，员工超过 2,000 人。

;

;中国通过苏伊士投资实现“一带一路”的雄心

;

;中国公司参与了埃及的许多其他项目，包括在该国新行政首都建设新的中央商务区——这是中国建筑工程总公司大规模开发项目的一部分。

;

;John Calabrese 博士，高级研究员位于华盛顿的中东研究所研究员表示，中国投资者被吸引到埃及是因为它位于海湾、非洲和欧洲的交汇处。

;

;Calabrese 表示，苏伊士运河和多式联运连接中国一直是现代化的关键，构成了将中国与所有这三个区域市场以及能源和其他关键原材料联系起来的商业动脉。

;

;“这正是我认为埃及拥有在“一带一路”倡议的设计和执行中发挥了如此重要的作用，”卡拉布雷斯说。

;

;他说，“北京和开罗之间的政治和制度相似性，以及对国家主导发展的共同偏好，有助于加强经济合作的力量”。

;

;然而，卡拉布雷斯表示，鉴于埃及近期和当前的经济困境，中国存在风险。 “但没有人希望埃及失败，这可能会有所帮助，”他说。

;

;日本、印度和中东的公司也一直在关注苏伊士运河附近的机会。

;

;当日本人日本首相岸田文雄4月下旬访问埃及，承诺日本企业将投资苏伊士运河经济区。 Calabrese 表示，他对日本加入这场游戏并不感到意外，因为在过去一年或更长时间里，他们一直在寻求促进与沙特阿拉伯和阿拉伯联合酋长国的投资和其他关系。

;

;“东京几乎肯定会考虑埃及作为通往非洲的门户，就像北京所做的那样。鉴于对海上天然气开采的兴趣，我预计欧盟 [或] 欧洲的参与也会增加，”卡拉布雷斯说。

;

;中国表示正在与沙特阿拉伯和埃及谈判武器交易

; p>;不过，索利曼表示，虽然中国企业一直是运河经济区的重要投资者，但这并不一定意味着他们在所有领域都占据主导地位。

;

;“日本有自己的经济利益和能力，可以为该地区的发展，”Soliman 说。

;

;他说，随着苏伊士运河经济区的不断发展和吸引资金，日本公司可能会进军并参与其发展，这取决于所提供的机会和激励措施

;

;“SCZONE 的发展旨在吸引来自不同来源的投资并促进国际合作，”Soliman 说。

;印度反对党领袖拉胡尔·甘地对国家领导人提出批评，呼吁印度人在美国和国内为民主和印度宪法挺身而出。

;

;甘地是印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪的尖锐批评者，他被驱逐出议会，指责莫迪和他的印度人民党 (BJP)分裂国家，未能关注失业和教育等重要问题。

;

;“对人下流、傲慢、暴力，这些都不是印度的价值观，”52 岁的甘地，周日在曼哈顿雅各布贾维茨中心举行的印度海外大会美国活动上对大约 700 人说。在默哀一分钟后，他发表了讲话，承认印度东部发生了大规模的火车出轨事故，造成 275 人死亡，数百人受伤。

;

;甘地一直在美国的三个城市进行巡回演出，包括在加利福尼亚州斯坦福大学和华盛顿国家新闻俱乐部。

;

;与此同时，美国国会领导人已邀请莫迪在本月晚些时候的国会联席会议上发表讲话。众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡、参议院多数党领袖查克·舒默和其他领导人宣布，此次演讲是“分享你们对印度未来的愿景并就我们两国共同面临的全球挑战发表意见的机会”。

;

;前印度人的孙子印度总理英迪拉·甘地拉胡尔·甘地是印度国大党的成员。他被认为是莫迪在 2024 年选举中的主要挑战者。

;

;“如果没有我们的宪法和我们的民主，现代印度就不可能存在，”他周日表示。他还敦促印度和美国加强伙伴关系，以抵消中国的影响。

;

;“我们必须考虑的事情之一是印度和美国之间的桥梁，”他说。 “我们如何应对中国人摆在桌面上的挑战，”他问道，特别提到了流动性和世界能源供应问题。

;

;国会在卡纳塔克邦击败莫迪领导的人民党对印度意味着什么2024 年选举

;

;国大党在喜马偕尔邦和卡纳塔克邦最近的邦选举中击败了印度人民党，这是继 2014 年莫迪成为印度总理后一系列邦选举失败后取得的胜利。甘地现在没有在他的党内担任正式职务。在 2019 年全国大选中惨败于莫迪的印度教民族主义政党之后，他放弃了党主席一职，尽管他的支持者希望最近的结果将影响明年可能在 5 月之前举行的全国大选。

;

;甘地在 3 月遭遇严重挫折，当时法院判定他在诽谤刑事案件中嘲笑莫迪的姓氏，这一决定导致他被驱逐出议会。如果上诉法院不推翻对他的定罪，他可能会在未来八年内失去竞选议会席位的资格。定罪与他在 2019 年发表的一次演讲有关。

;

;与圣雄甘地没有亲戚关系的甘地也在演讲中多次提到被暗杀的印度领导人的名字，赞扬他的非暴力模式.

; Mon, 05 Jun 2023 15:20:01 +0800 Hong Kong finance sector on the hook to deploy AI responsibly, says market watchdog’s CEOhttps://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/3222954/hong-kong-finance-sector-hook-deploy-ai-responsibly-says-market-watchdogs-ceo?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.05 13:36;
;;

;香港的资产管理者不应该害怕人工智能 (AI) 丢掉工作，但证券及期货事务监察委员会 (SFC) 首席执行官表示，金融部门必须谨慎地负责任地部署该技术，同时抓住它带来的机遇。

;

;“我们正处于另一场革命的风口浪尖，将改变我们的生活、工作和娱乐方式，”Julia Leung Fung-yee 周一在香港投资基金协会会议上表示。 “随着 AI 竞争的升温，技术专家将生成式 AI 比作芯片的发现。”

;

;资产管理者可能会采用生成式 AI 聊天机器人作为工具，并且不必担心被取代，因为 AI 将“释放时间和资产管理者更好地制定战略和执行的能力”，Leung 说。

;

;“我相信生成式 AI 可以负责任地用于增强而不是取代资产管理者的战略决策制定。”

;< p>;她补充说，作为香港的监管机构，证监会旨在促进技术的“负责任部署”，只要它能提高市场效率和透明度、节省成本和投资者体验。

;

;“现阶段，公司必须对 [AI] 输出持保留态度，对 AI 相关风险保持警惕，并确保客户得到公平对待，”Leung 说。

;

;公司必须在部署之前彻底测试 AI 应用程序，有她说，合格的员工管理人工智能工具，高级管理层监督到位，并确保围绕人工智能应用程序建立健全的治理框架。

;

;银行业需要更多金融科技和绿色金融方面的培训：金管局官员

;

;“对于任何违反行为的行为，证监会希望追究持牌公司的责任，而不是人工智能，”她补充说。

;

;自从香港最后一次 Covid-19 限制被取消和大陆以来Leung 表示，边境重新开放后，货币市场基金、短期债券、平衡基金和保险公司的委托资金都出现了强劲流入，尤其是那些拥有大型零售网络的金融机构。

;

;然而，这座城市她说，未来的复苏还有很长的路要走，必须保持“警惕和弹性”。

;

;在大流行期间加速的行业数字化允许一些银行流程，例如开户和到期私人财富管理协会执行委员会主席 Amy Lo 在会议的另一场会议上表示，尽职调查会更快地发生。

;

;该行业应该“利用”这一数字化转型的机遇，瑞银香港首席执行官兼该公司亚太区财富管理联席主管 Lo 表示，将其财富管理实践转变为更加“混合”。然而，她补充说，这个过程的某些部分，比如客户讨论，总是需要“人情味”。

;

;香港银行公会代理主席陈志伟也表达了这些观点，他说客户希望在银行业务方面获得增强的“全渠道体验”。

;

;客户可以自由利用在线资源、AI 聊天机器人服务和面对面的客户服务与银行互动。

;

;“[银行业]要取得平衡将是一个挑战，”Chan 说，并补充说该行业必须记住“不要只是把所有东西都放在网上”，因为客户服务仍然非常重要。

;

;与此同时，区块链通过实现更快、更安全的分配来帮助彻底改变跨境交易，而人工智能驱动的平台可以通过提供量身定制的建议来个性化财富管理，通过减少响应时间和人为错误来提高客户服务效率，他说。

;

;“事实证明，技术在银行业的整合对我们所有人都有好处，”Chan 说。

;

;展望未来，银行业的未来将以Chan 说，通过人工智能和大数据增强个性化。同样，虽然技术将简化流程，但在技术开发、人工智能、数据分析和网络安全等领域也将创造新的就业机会。

;Global Impact 是一份精选的每周时事通讯，其特色是源自中国的新闻主题，具有重要意义对我们在世界各地的新闻阅读者的宏观影响。注册

;

;Turnabout 是公平竞争。 That must be the mood in Beijing right now after the Cyberspace Administration of China concluded its security review into Micron last month, ruling that the last company producing memory chips in the US poses a risk and can no longer sell to key information infrastructure operators, a broad category that effectively bars all sales in the country.

;

;This cybersecurity review unfolded pretty quickly. Compare it to the one against Didi Chuxing, one of the first examples of Beijing using this power. The government effectively left China's ride-hailing champion to twist in the wind for more than a year after it went public in the US.

;

;The Micron investigation, on the other hand, was just launched in March. This was Beijing's big push back against Washington's escalating chip export restrictions to China (which, including collaboration with allies, seem to get stricter by the month).

;

;However, the move betrays the limited options available to Beijing. Micron chips are comparatively easy to replace. While Washington has urged South Korea to not let rivals Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fill the market gap in Micron's absence, there is no guarantee they will not benefit.

;

;China also sees room to boost domestic companies, especially the country's largest memory chip maker, Yangtze Memory Technologies Corp (YMTC), despite the company being sanctioned by Washington.

;

;With signs that the market for memory chips may be bottoming out, YMTC has moved earlier than rivals to increase prices on its 3D NAND flash memory.

;

;There have already been some immediate effects of the Micron ban. China's top server makers, including Inspur and Lenovo, told suppliers to stop shipping components with the US company's chips.

;

;News of the ban also helped boost shares of domestic chip companies, which surged on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges. Something similar happened in March when the launch of the Micron probe pushed the CNI Chip Index up by over 5 per cent.

;

;Lest the market get too excited, though, Beijing moved quickly to taper expectations of further escalation. Nationalist tabloid, the Global Times, described the move as an individual case, and China's minister of commerce said the country still welcomes US business investment.

;

;A telling sign of the limits of Beijing's retaliatory options is its decision so far to avoid targeting logic chips like those from Intel, Qualcomm and Nvidia. Domestic production capabilities of advanced logic chips remain much further behind, and those chips are needed to power servers, smartphones and artificial intelligence applications. China's AI ambitions have already been set back by restrictions on certain Nvidia chips.

;

;Beijing has also been frustrated by Washington's multilateral approach to countering China's technological advance. Beyond just South Korea, the US has been working with Japan and the Netherlands to ensure its export restrictions are enforced.

;

;China slams Japan's semiconductor technology export controls

;

;Last month, China's Ministry of Commerce condemned Japan's decision to update export controls to cover 23 types of chip-making technology, affecting around 10 companies. The move will “severely damage” the two countries' “economic and trade cooperation”, the ministry said.

;

;Experts say the move will further constrain China's ability to expand chip production capacity, especially at the 20-nanometre level and more advanced.

;

;Meanwhile, Japan could be set to help Micron expand to the tune of US$1.5 billion in financial incentives for a new plant in the country. The company is also expanding in the US, where it is building a plant in New York.

;

;In an effort to show it still has clout with its neighbours, China issued a statement last month saying it had reached an agreement with South Korea during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation trade ministers' meeting in Detroit to boost semiconductor cooperation.

;

;Chinese chip maker CXMT hits out at anti-globalisation in semiconductor sector

;

;Seoul made no mention of “cooperation”, saying only that the two countries had discussed stabilising the supply and demand of raw materials and parts.

;

;Another risk for Beijing is that the Micron ban could result in additional blowback, even as Washington already seems intent on pushing the limits of trade restrictions.

;

;One American lawmaker said the US should take action against Changxin Memory Technologies (CXMT). This is one of the dynamic random-access memory chip makers that analysts said could benefit from Micron's absence.

;

;Last year, CXMT CEO Zhu Yiming warned of the harms from anti-globalisation sentiment, and now it seems his fears could be realised, just as one of his biggest foreign rivals is pushed out of the domestic market.

;The Chinese government on Sunday banned the sale of certain Micron Technology products to key information infrastructure operators in the country, citing “cybersecurity risks”, in Beijing's most forceful retaliation in the Sino-US tech war.

;

;The following timeline highlights Micron's key developments since its entry into China over two decades ago, and shows how the US company went from a welcome business partner to a target of Beijing's national security investigation.

;Micron Technology, the United States' largest memory chip maker, has become the first foreign semiconductor company to be put under a cybersecurity review by China, months after the American tech firm closed its DRAM design operations in Shanghai at the end of last year.

;

;The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) said in a statement on Friday that it launched an investigation into Micron's products in China to “safeguard key information infrastructure supply chain security” and “prevent cyberspace security risks due to problematic products”.

; US firm

;

;Chinese solid-state drive (SSD) maker Beijing Memblaze Technology Co, a major buyer of memory chips from Micron Technology, retracted its Shanghai public listing in late March, just days before Beijing opened a cybersecurity investigation into the US company.

;

;While there is no evidence that directly links the aborted initial public offering of Memblaze to Micron, the Chinese firm's move to ditch its listing was in proximity – three days – to the US firm being put under investigation by the Cyber Security Review Office under the Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) on national security grounds.

;

;China's top memory chip maker Yangtze Memory Technologies Corp (YMTC) has significantly cut orders for production equipment in recent months, according to an industry source, a sign that its expansion plans have been dealt a major blow by Washington's efforts to deny Chinese access to advanced chip-making technologies.

;

;Based in Wuhan, capital of central Hubei province, YMTC has slashed up to 70 per cent of its orders from Naura Technology Group, a leading Chinese maker of etching, cleaning and chemical vapour deposition tools for wafer fabs, according to a source familiar with the matter, who declined to be named as he was not authorised to speak with media.

The move has fanned concerns among buyers in the country that they would continue to face escalating curbs on equipment purchases, according to two people involved in the semiconductor supply chain, who declined to be named due to the sensitivity of the matter.

;Using language aimed primarily at a domestic audience, Li also tried to be creative in his rhetoric, as he threw punches at Washington.

;

;In his Sunday address, he used two idioms – ge jiu cai, “to harvest Chinese chives” and hao yang mao, “to shear sheep wool” – as he accused the US, without naming it, of “speculating in creating troubles and crisis” in the region.

;

;Zhou Chenming, a researcher from the Beijing-based Yuan Wang military science and technology think tank, said Li's confidence on the international stage came from his princeling and academic backgrounds.

;

;“Li holds an engineering doctorate in control theory and control engineering from Chongqing University, but his academic background doesn't mean he is a weak leader,” Zhou said.

;

;Big powers must avoid 'diplomatic freezes' for stable world order: Australian PM

;

;He also noted that, unlike his predecessors in China's defence portfolio, Li comes from a military family.

;

;Li's late father Li Shaozhu was a Red Army veteran who fought in the anti-Japanese war of the late 1930s and 1940s. He was also well-known for his role in rebuilding logistical railways during the civil war and Korean war which followed.

;

;The senior Li was later put in charge of the PLA's strategic Railway Force in the southwestern border regions of Tibet and Yunnan from the 1950s to 1970s.

;

;Zhou said Li's first international trip since becoming defence minister in March – a four-day visit to Russia in April – also carried an important signal to Washington.

;

;“His decision to visit Moscow and talk to Russian President Vladimir Putin … indicated he would not bow to the American sanctions,” he said.

;

;Chinese defence minister 'specifically chose Russia' for first overseas trip

;

;Li followed his father's footsteps, joining the army in 1978 as a 20-year-old student with the National University of Defence and Technology. Four years later, he joined China's manned space programme, kicking off a 31-year adventure in space exploration at the Xichang Satellite Launch Centre.

;

;In 2013, Li moved to the then general armament department – at that time one of the PLA's four headquarters – as a top adviser. In President Xi Jinping's unprecedented 2016 overhaul of the military, Li was appointed deputy commander of the newly established Strategic Support Force.

;

;Li's successes at the Singapore forum included meetings with top defence officials from the host nation as well as Seoul, Tokyo, Manila, Berlin, Wellington and Ulaanbaatar.

;

;There was no bilateral meeting with Canada, which sent a frigate to accompany a US destroyer transiting the Taiwan Strait on Saturday.

;

;Shangri-La Dialogue: US and China stand ground on Taiwan, South China Sea

;

;The much anticipated meeting with the US defence chief also did not occur, and Beijing has blamed Washington for the omission.

;

;“Washington should have lifted Li's sanctions when he left the equipment department to head the defence ministry in October last year. It's a basic diplomatic protocol,” said Lieutenant General He Lei, a former deputy director of the PLA Academy of Military Science, who was among the Chinese delegation.

;

;Zhou Bo, a senior fellow at Tsinghua University's Centre for International Security and Strategy and a guest at the Dialogue, said the consequences of no meetings or communication between the military heads of the world's two superpowers would be “very serious”.

;

;“One official term of a Chinese defence minister is up to five years, and he is the specific leader who oversees military diplomacy,” Zhou said.

;

;“Does this mean both sides do not want to talk in the coming five years? So the US must lift the sanctions first. It's a knot Beijing and Washington should use their wisdom to untie.”

;American, Chinese, and Russian navy ships are due to join exercises in Indonesian waters on Monday to drill responses to humanitarian disasters, in a rare moment of cooperation during a rancorous period of diplomacy and heightened defence competition across the Asia-Pacific.

;

;Indonesia, which deftly handled last year's G20 meeting in Bali in the shadow of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, is playing host to the Komodo naval exercises in the Makassar Strait until Thursday.

;

;The event comes days after the Shangri-la Dialogue defence summit in Singapore ended in a new bout of mudslinging between Chinese and US defence chiefs with the status of Taiwan the focal point.

;

;Held in waters between Borneo and Sulawesi, the exercise brings together 49 countries including sworn geopolitical rivals – such as North and South Korea, and India and Pakistan – as experts say Asean chair Indonesia quietly fills the role of neutral broker in a region scored by competing claims to seas and territories.

;

;“These interactions tend to focus more on engagement but the geopolitical realities are there for all to see,” said Prashanth Parameswaran, a fellow at the US-based Wilson Centre think tank.

;

;“Indonesia has been at the heart of managing these tensions over the past couple of years, with its chairmanship of G20 last year and Asean this year.”

;

;An avowedly neutral country committed to a “free and active” foreign policy, Indonesia appears intent on exerting a greater international role to match its place as Southeast Asia's largest economy and status as the world's fourth-most populous nation.

;

;President Joko Widodo is expected to open the event following a slew of high-profile international appearances after Indonesia chaired the G20 and Asean and attended the G7.

;

;Jokowi the kingmaker? Search for a successor grips Indonesia's ruling party

;

;The cast of countries is “in line with the international status and standing of Indonesia, as one of the motives of the country's defence diplomacy is to enhance its international image and reputation,” said Frega Wenas, a lecturer at Indonesia's National Defence University.

;

;“With the attendance of major power countries such as the US, China and many other countries, the exercise will provide an opportunity for dialogue as the chiefs of navy will also meet up in parallel with the operational activities at sea.”

;

;The Komodo exercises will include sea rescues and responses to humanitarian emergencies such as natural disasters. Yet diplomatic outreach – a duty of the Indonesian navy – seems just as significant.

;

;Alongside the naval manoeuvres are lighter events including a city parade, a culinary programme and a maritime exhibition.

;

;Asked by This Week in Asia whether tensions with Russia and China might cause friction during the Komodo exercise, a US Navy spokesman said: “We respect the government of Indonesia's ability to select participants in its host-nation capacity.

;

;“The United States will continue work with partners, such as Indonesia, to ensure that the region remains open and accessible and that the region's seas and skies are governed and used according to international law.”

;

;Representatives of the Russian embassy in Jakarta declined to comment.

;

;China's nationalist Global Times tabloid said the country's participation in the exercise was aimed at boosting “understanding, exchanges and communication with foreign militaries to safeguard peace and stability amid rising tensions in the Asia-Pacific.”

;

;Shangri-La Dialogue: Chinese general hits out at Lloyd Austin over Taiwan

;

;Yet days before the drills got under way, geopolitical tensions reared up at Singapore's Shangri-La Dialogue. China refused America's proposal for a customary meeting between their defence chiefs citing sanctions levelled at Li Shangfu, China's Minister of National Defence.

;

;US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin responded with a veiled swipe in a speech: “For responsible defence leaders, the right time to talk is any time. The right time to talk is every time, and the right time to talk is now.”

;

;Meanwhile, in the Taiwan Strait a Chinese warship came within 150 yards of hitting the US destroyer USS Chung-Hoon, after American and Canadian warships sailed through the sensitive waterway.

;

;Both Beijing and Washington have been building up their security relationships with states in the Asia-Pacific recently.

;

;This week a concurrent set of naval exercises is taking place involving the Philippines, the US, and Japan. Philippine authorities insist the exercise is nothing out of the ordinary.

;

;Even the avowedly neutral Indonesia has not been untouched by rising tensions. While China is attending the multilateral Komodo exercise, bilateral exercises with Indonesia have not been held since 2014.

;

;The drills were put on hold amid an ongoing dispute about Beijing's maritime claims in the South China Sea.

;

;“Given that the country will have a new president following elections next year … the question of the future direction of Indonesia's wider foreign and defence policy is looming,” Parameswaran said.

;With three denizens of the Republican establishment launching presidential campaigns this week in the United States, the race for the 2024 nomination has begun to resemble the sprawling 2016 field that proved a huge boon to unfancied outsider Donald Trump.

;

;This time the 76-year-old tycoon is the runaway front runner but the conventional wisdom remains the same: the larger the chasing pack, the more likely he is to win by dividing the anti-Trump vote.

;

;Former New Jersey governor Chris Christie, who was trounced by Trump in 2016, is expected to launch a fresh tilt at the White House on Tuesday, a day ahead of ex-vice president Mike Pence and North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum.

;

;Christie, who will announce in New Hampshire, presents a novel challenge as the only contender so far willing to land genuinely damaging blows on Trump as he makes his case for four years in the Oval Office.

;

;The 60-year-old Newark native has already begun needling his former friend, arguing last month that the former reality TV star and real estate tycoon was “afraid” of debating serious opponents.

;

;Trump has indicated that he may skip at least one of the first two debates, expressing a reluctance to share the limelight with lower-polling rivals.

;

;“If he really cares about the country – and I have deep questions about that – but if he really cares about the country, then he's going to get up there, and he shouldn't be afraid,” Christie told radio host Hugh Hewitt.

;

;The former federal prosecutor came in sixth in New Hampshire seven years ago and eventually endorsed Trump, serving as a key adviser before the pair had a high-profile falling out.

;

;Trump and DeSantis trade jabs on 2024 campaign trail

;

;Christie has since assailed Trump on all manner of issues, highlighting the escalating criminal probes targeting the embattled billionaire, trashing his false claims of election fraud and dubbing him “Putin's puppet” over his isolationist stance on Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

;

;Trump revealed that he relishes the chaos of a crowded field when he welcomed his first serious opponent, former South Carolina governor Nikki Haley, to the race in February, telling Fox News: “The more the merrier”.

;

;But John Ellis, a former head of the network's Election Night Decision Desk, said Christie's candidacy could put Trump on the back foot.

;

;“Because he will attack Trump relentlessly, Christie's campaign will get a ton of coverage in the mainstream press, which may help him do well in New Hampshire,” said Ellis, founder of the News Items current affairs newsletter.

;

;“Favourable press coverage catapulted John McCain's presidential campaign in New Hampshire in 2000. Christie is making the same bet. Regardless, having someone hammering you every day is never helpful to the front runner.”

;

;By midweek there will be 10 major candidates in the Republican primary and another four also-rans, but Trump has a 30-plus point lead over his closest rival, Ron DeSantis, the Florida governor.

;

;Pence, Trump's unwaveringly loyal vice-president turned reluctant critic, is expected to launch his campaign on Wednesday, ahead of a CNN Town Hall in Iowa.

;

;His launch, along with Christie's, complicates the race less for Trump than for DeSantis, who has been on a charm offensive in the first-in-the-nation voting states of Iowa and New Hampshire as he bids to remain competitive.

;

;The governor's efforts to keep the emphasis on “charm” rather than “offensive” – softening the edges of reputation for aloofness – were undermined Thursday by a temper tantrum he had at a reporter in the lakeside town of Laconia.

;

;The hardline conservative is running to Trump's right in what political analysts have called a “last man standing” campaign that banks on the former president being taken out of contention by the escalating legal threats he faces.

;

;The strategy, according to the theory, is essentially to keep Trump's supporters content by avoiding too much conflict and being best placed to mop them up when their man is forced to bow out.

;

;But 44-year-old DeSantis has also begun to fire off explicit broadsides against his rival, questioning the front-runner's commitment to conservatism, his effectiveness in office and his prospects of victory against President Joe Biden.

;

;President Trump 2.0 may start a full-on cold war with China

;

;Liberals watching the race with a mixture of amusement and horror have been split between those cheering on Trump, believing he will be the easiest one to beat in the general election, and those who would rather see anyone else prevail, even if it means losing the White House.

;

;“The opponents in the Republican primary can try their hardest, but if rape allegations and an insurrection couldn't waiver Trump's base, these candidates will not either,” said Democratic election strategist Amani Wells-Onyioha.
